name: Ming
story:
<|begin_of_text|>Write a 500 words story about a character whose name is Ming. Provide only the story, no extra context or explanation. 

Ming sat at her desk, staring blankly at the blank sheet of paper in front of her. It was the third day of her residency orientation, and so far, she hadn't written a single word. Her mind was a jumble of anxiety and excitement, a mix of emotions that seemed to shift by the minute.

She pushed back her chair and stood up, stretching her arms overhead. Her fingers were stiff from hours of tapping on her keyboard, and her eyes felt gritty from staring at the screen. Ming wandered over to the window and gazed out at the city, trying to clear her head.

The sun was setting over the skyscrapers, casting long shadows across the streets. It was a beautiful sight, but Ming's thoughts kept drifting back to her first day of residency. She had come into the hospital feeling like a fish out of water, unsure of what to expect or how she was supposed to adapt to the fast-paced environment.

As she stood there, a memory flashed into her mind - her own mentor, Dr. Lee, on her first day of medicine rotations. She had been equally lost, equally terrified of making mistakes and disappointing her patients. But Dr. Lee had taken her under his wing, guiding her through the chaos with a steady hand and a reassuring smile.

Ming felt a pang of gratitude towards her own mentor, Dr. Patel. She was just as kind and wise as Dr. Lee, with a wicked sense of humor to boot. But Ming's thoughts kept circling back to her own vulnerability. She was a resident now, not a student. She was supposed to be a professional, confident in her abilities and her knowledge.

The thought was almost laughable. Ming felt like she was walking around in a perpetual state of confusion, uncertain of what was expected of her or how to meet expectations. She sat back down at her desk, took a deep breath, and began to type.

At first, the words flowed steadily, a mixture of thoughts and impressions that she was trying to process. But as the minutes ticked by, Ming found herself getting more and more abstract. Paragraphs morphed into poetry, and poetry devolved into loose, impressionistic fragments. It was like she was trying to describe the color of a sunset or the sound of her own heartbeat.

When she finally stopped typing, Ming felt worn out but strangely, exhilarated. She had tapped into a part of herself that she didn't know existed, a deep well of creativity that was just waiting to be explored. It was a fragile thread, a promise of things to come, but it was enough to get her through the next few days of residency - one paragraph at a time.

As she saved her document and closed her laptop, Ming felt a glimmer of hope. Maybe this residency thing was going to be okay after all. And maybe, just maybe, she would learn to find her own voice, her own confidence, in the midst of all this noise and chaos. For now, it was enough to hold onto a single thread of thought, a single thread of light. Anything more would be too much to bear. Anything less would be too small to speak of. And yet, as she leaned forward to stare out the window at the city below, Ming felt a sense that something was on the rise, a glimmer of hope on the edge of a new beginning. It felt small and insignificant compared to the rest of the world, but as she sat back in her chair, something shifted inside of her. A tiny spark appeared, growing with each passing moment. And that's all Ming needed. A little spark. A little bit of hope. To keep her going for a little while longer. To keep her moving, stepping forward into the unknown, and finding a new sense of place for herself in the world.

Keep in mind, as you continue the story, you don't need to stick to the exact prompts for each section.
